title: Train fare dodger who taunted company on social media is caught and fined £1,225
text:
Train fare dodger who taunted company on social media is caught and fined £1,225 Richard Ruddy dodged multiple train fares and ridiculed South West Trains for a year on Twitter Telegraph Reporters 26 January 2017 • 11:19pm 
A train fare dodger who goaded a rail company on social media with taunts of "catch me if you can" has finally been caught and fined 25 times more than the original fares. 
Richard Ruddy dodged multiple train fares and ridiculed South West Trains for a year on Twitter , bragging that the firm were "saving him money". What makes it worse is that you were mocking the staff and putting their photos on Twitter without their permission Magistrate Simon Browning 
T he 25-year-old chef sent dozens of tweets to the rail firm, asking them to "come get me" while he was on board without a ticket. 
In another, he gloated he had "convinced the ageing train assistant he'd already seen his ticket", adding that it was one-nil to him. 
Salisbury Magistrates' Court heard Ruddy also mocked South West Trains by taking photos of their staff and uploading them to Twitter without permission. 
The court heard he was only caught when a South West Trains worker came across his twitter page and reported him. Just no when the ticket man is scoffing a cream cake on carriage 1 if you sit in carriage 4 your home and dry @SW_Trains — Rich Gshore (@tbramble19) February 21, 2016 
R uddy, who used the service to get to work, was told he must pay back £48.10 worth of fares he swindled over 12 trips as well as a £1,225 fine. 
Paul Jones, defending Ruddy, of Poole, Dorset, said he used the service between Branksome and Christchurch, both Dorset, and said his client "could not believe that the tickets were not checked". Convinced the aging train assistant he'd already seen my ticket at branksome, to which he apologised. @tbramble19 1 @SW_Trains 0 #morning — Rich Gshore (@tbramble19) March 18, 2016 
M agistrate Simon Browning said it was the worst such case he had experienced. Mr Browning also said: "You were goading the company on Twitter, and what makes it worse is that you were mocking the staff and putting their photos on Twitter without their permission." 
A spokesman from South West Trains said: "Every year, passengers are deprived of millions of pounds worth of potential improvements to their train services, as a direct result of deliberate fare evasion." 
Ruddy must also complete 120 hours of unpaid work. Follow Telegraph News
